elements.content: The diffusion reaction of TBA2CuIICl4 (TBA = tetrabutylammonium) and a N-containing organic donor, BP-TTF [=bis(pyrazino)tetrathiafulvalene], yielded a 3-D supramolecular Cu complex, [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] (1). The magnetic measurement of 1 exhibits an antiferromagnetic interaction by fitting a Bonner−Fisher model from 2 to 300 K with S = 1/2 and J = −3.5 K between CuΙΙ mediated by self-assembling donor columns.
elements.clean_text: The diffusion reaction of TBA2CuIICl4 (TBA = tetrabutylammonium) and a N-containing organic donor, BP-TTF [=bis(pyrazino)tetrathiafulvalene], yielded a 3-D supramolecular Cu complex, [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] (1). The magnetic measurement of 1 exhibits an antiferromagnetic interaction by fitting a Bonner-Fisher model from 2 to 300 K with S = 1/2 and J = -3.5 K between CuΙΙ mediated by self-assembling donor columns.

elements.content: The diffusion reaction of TBA2CuIICl4 (TBA = tetrabutylammonium) and a N-containing organic donor, BP-TTF [=bis(pyrazino)tetrathiafulvalene], yielded a 3-D supramolecular Cu complex, [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] (1). The magnetic measurement of 1 exhibits an antiferromagnetic interaction by fitting a Bonner−Fisher model from 2 to 300 K with S = 1/2 and J = −3.5 K between CuΙΙ mediated by self-assembling donor columns.
elements.clean_text: The diffusion reaction of TBA2CuIICl4 (TBA = tetrabutylammonium) and a N-containing organic donor, BP-TTF [=bis(pyrazino)tetrathiafulvalene], yielded a 3-D supramolecular Cu complex, [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] (1). The magnetic measurement of 1 exhibits an antiferromagnetic interaction by fitting a Bonner-Fisher model from 2 to 300 K with S = 1/2 and J = -3.5 K between CuΙΙ mediated by self-assembling donor columns.

elements.content: The molecular-based multifunctional materials have attracted great interests owing to a large degree of freedom in spin, charge, lattice, and designable molecules. Especially, the materials with conductivity and magnetism have been intensively investigated in the experimental and theoretical aspects. Among them, metal complexes coordinated by organic donors have a smaller donor−metal distance than those of ordinary noncoordination charge transfer complexes and possess an ability to construct self-assembling donor columns or layers. Therefore, this system is expected to exhibit π−d interactions. For example, the radical cation salt of the CuII complex, [CuII(hfac)2(TTF-py)2](PF6)2·2CH2Cl2 [hfac = hexafluoroacetylacetonate and TTF-py = 4-(2-tetrathiafulvalenylethenyl)pyridine); Figure ], contains TTF moieties substituted by a pyridinylethene function as cation ligands. Although magnetic and conducting systems are covalently linked through a delocalized bridge, the magnetic interaction is not so large, with θ = −3.8 K owing to the long distance between the spin and charge sources. Other novel CuI complexes coordinated to ET [=bis(ethylenedithio)tetrathiafulvalene] are (ET)CuI 2Br4, (ET)2CuI 6Br9, (ET)2[Cu4Br6ET], (ET)2CuI 2Br4, (ET)2CuI 3Br7(H2O), and (ET)2CuI 6Br10, where ET molecules are coordinated to Cu ions with the S atoms of the ethylenedithio groups in various coordination modes, such as monodentate, trans-bidentate, and cis-bidentate. These materials are conducting but diamagnetic owing to CuI. Much more than a S atom, a N atom is a good Lewis base, so that N-containing organic donors could be good candidates as ligands. Therefore, we have first synthesized the supramolecular Cu complex, where CuII is coordinated by the pyrazino-fused TTF as a ligand, [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] (Figure ). Herein, the preparation, X-ray crystal structure analysis, and measurements of the magnetic and electrical properties of 1 are reported.
elements.clean_text: The molecular-based multifunctional materials have attracted great interests owing to a large degree of freedom in spin, charge, lattice, and designable molecules. Especially, the materials with conductivity and magnetism have been intensively investigated in the experimental and theoretical aspects. Among them, metal complexes coordinated by organic donors have a smaller donor-metal distance than those of ordinary noncoordination charge transfer complexes and possess an ability to construct self-assembling donor columns or layers. Therefore, this system is expected to exhibit π-d interactions. For example, the radical cation salt of the CuII complex, [CuII(hfac)2(TTF-py)2](PF6)2⋅2CH2Cl2 [hfac = hexafluoroacetylacetonate and TTF-py = 4-(2-tetrathiafulvalenylethenyl)pyridine); Figure ], contains TTF moieties substituted by a pyridinylethene function as cation ligands. Although magnetic and conducting systems are covalently linked through a delocalized bridge, the magnetic interaction is not so large, with θ = -3.8 K owing to the long distance between the spin and charge sources. Other novel CuI complexes coordinated to ET [=bis(ethylenedithio)tetrathiafulvalene] are (ET)CuI 2Br4, (ET)2CuI 6Br9, (ET)2[Cu4Br6ET], (ET)2CuI 2Br4, (ET)2CuI 3Br7(H2O), and (ET)2CuI 6Br10, where ET molecules are coordinated to Cu ions with the S atoms of the ethylenedithio groups in various coordination modes, such as monodentate, trans-bidentate, and cis-bidentate. These materials are conducting but diamagnetic owing to CuI. Much more than a S atom, a N atom is a good Lewis base, so that N-containing organic donors could be good candidates as ligands. Therefore, we have first synthesized the supramolecular Cu complex, where CuII is coordinated by the pyrazino-fused TTF as a ligand, [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] (Figure ). Herein, the preparation, X-ray crystal structure analysis, and measurements of the magnetic and electrical properties of 1 are reported.

elements.content: Molecular structures of TTF-py and BP-TTF.
elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular structures of TTF-py and BP-TTF.

elements.content: BP-TTF was synthesized as described in the literature. The Cu complex [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] was prepared by a diffusion method; BP-TTF (10 mg) in CHCl3 and TBA2CuCl4 (223 mg) in dry CH3OH were added in the diffusion cell under a N2 atmosphere. After about 2 weeks, black needle crystals of [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] were collected by filtration and washed with dry CH3OH. The composition of this complex was determined by scanning electron microscopy−energy-dispersive spectrometry (JEOL JCM-5000 and Oxford WDX 400 spectrometers) and structure analysis.
elements.clean_text: BP-TTF was synthesized as described in the literature. The Cu complex [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] was prepared by a diffusion method; BP-TTF (10 mg) in CHCl3 and TBA2CuCl4 (223 mg) in dry CH3OH were added in the diffusion cell under a N2 atmosphere. After about 2 weeks, black needle crystals of [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] were collected by filtration and washed with dry CH3OH. The composition of this complex was determined by scanning electron microscopy-energy-dispersive spectrometry (JEOL JCM-5000 and Oxford WDX 400 spectrometers) and structure analysis.

elements.content: The X-ray single crystal analysis of 1 shows the 3-D supramolecular network, as shown in Figure a,b. The zigzag [CuIICl2(BP-TTF)] n chain extends along the b axis, where the CuII atom in a planar geometry is coordinated by two Cl- and two N atoms of BP-TTF as ligands [Cu−Cl = 2.24 Å; Cu−N = 2.15 Å]. The Cu−Cl bond length is close to CuII distances; e.g., among CuII chlorides, one finds for ET3CuIICl4·H2O 2.25 Å, for [(C2H5)2NH2]CuIICl4 2.254 Å, and for [(R n H4 - n )N]2CuΙΙCl4 2.252 Å, while for CuI chlorides, one finds for α‘-ET2CuICl2 2.086 Å, for β‘-ET2CuICl2 2.098 Å, and for [(CH3)4N]CuICl2 2.107 Å. The nonparallel alignment of the Cl−Cu−Cl fragment with respect to the ligand donor plane by 45° is to satisfy a sizable C−H···Cl hydrogen bond (2.80 Å). On the other hand, the donors form uniform stacking columns to have the β-type donor arrangement with the ring over bond configuration. The donor's interplanar distance is 3.87 Å, which is almost the same as that of TMTSF2PF6 (TMTSF = tetramethyltetraselenafulvalene) of 3.8−4.0 Å. The molecular orbital of BP-TTF including N atoms is calculated by WinMOPAC (version 3.9.0, Fujitsu Ltd.). Based upon the obtained orbitals, the overlap integrals are calculated to be r = −5.3, p = −0.2, and q = 0.6 (×10-3). The largest interactions, r, are observed in the donor stacking direction, whereas the smaller ones are obtained in the intercolumnar direction, p with the close N···S contacts (3.10 Å) and q as shown in Figure a,c. Therefore, the d−σ coordination along the b axis and the π−π interactions in the ac plane construct the 3-D supramolecular framework.
elements.clean_text: The X-ray single crystal analysis of 1 shows the 3-D supramolecular network, as shown in Figure a,b. The zigzag [CuIICl2(BP-TTF)] n  chain extends along the b axis, where  the CuII atom in a planar geometry is coordinated by two Cl- and two N atoms of BP-TTF as ligands [Cu-Cl = 2.24 Å; Cu-N = 2.15 Å]. The Cu-Cl bond length is close to CuII distances; e.g., among CuII chlorides, one finds for ET3CuIICl4⋅H2O 2.25 Å, for [(C2H5)2NH2]CuIICl4 2.254 Å, and for [(R n H4 -  n )N]2CuΙΙCl4 2.252 Å, while for CuI chlorides, one finds for α‘-ET2CuICl2 2.086 Å, for β‘-ET2CuICl2 2.098 Å, and for [(CH3)4N]CuICl2 2.107 Å. The nonparallel alignment of the Cl-Cu-Cl fragment with respect to the ligand donor plane by 45° is to satisfy a sizable C-H⋅⋅⋅Cl hydrogen bond (2.80 Å). On the other hand, the donors form uniform stacking columns to have the β-type donor arrangement with the ring over bond configuration. The donor's interplanar distance is 3.87 Å, which is almost the same as that of TMTSF2PF6 (TMTSF = tetramethyltetraselenafulvalene) of 3.8-4.0 Å. The molecular orbital of BP-TTF including N atoms is calculated by WinMOPAC (version 3.9.0, Fujitsu Ltd.). Based upon the obtained orbitals, the overlap integrals are calculated to be r = -5.3, p = -0.2, and q = 0.6 (×10-3). The largest interactions, r, are observed in the donor stacking direction, whereas the smaller ones are obtained in the intercolumnar direction, p with the close N⋅⋅⋅S contacts (3.10 Å) and q as shown in Figure a,c. Therefore, the d-σ coordination along the b axis and the π-π interactions in the ac plane construct the 3-D supramolecular framework.

elements.content: (a) Supramolecular [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] n chains and side-by-side N···S contacts as dashed lines, viewed along the c axis, (b) packing of the [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] n chains and the regular stacking donor columns viewed perpendicularly to the donor plane, and (c) donor arrangement of columns B and D of [CuCl2(BP-TTF)].
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Supramolecular [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] n  chains and side-by-side N⋅⋅⋅S contacts as dashed lines, viewed along the c axis, (b) packing of the [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] n  chains and the regular stacking donor columns viewed perpendicularly to the donor plane, and (c) donor arrangement of columns B and D of [CuCl2(BP-TTF)].

elements.content:
The resistivity measurement was performed on single crystals with carbon paint as four-probe contacts. The measurement at room temperature shows that [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] is an insulator.

To estimate the oxidation state of Cu, the electron spin resonance (ESR) measurement was carried out from 290 to 4 K with a Bruker EMS 9.3-GHz X-band ESR spectrometer equipped with an Oxford ITC305 cryostat. Figure shows the angular dependences of the g value and the line width for one Lorentzian signal of the single crystal, [CuCl2(BP-TTF)2], with the crystal orientation in Figure . The g value varies from 2.05 to 2.27 when the crystal is rotated about the pseudo-4-fold axis of CuIICl2N2 coordination in 1 with the static field perpendicular to this axis (θ rotation), while the g value in the ω rotation is much smaller and the line width is nearly 4-fold rotation. This result is similar to that of (BEDT-TTF)3CuIICl4·H2O, within the range for Jahn−Teller distorted CuIIX4 ions. Therefore, the Cu complex is expected to be [CuIICl2(BP-TTF)0] in correspondence with the insulating behavior without carriers. The temperature dependence of ESR measurements was carried out from 290 to 4 K in the magnetic field parallel and perpendicular to the c* axis. With lowering temperatures, the line widths decrease from 29 G (290 K) to 16 G (4 K) for H ⊥ c* and from 23 G (290 K) to 18 G (4 K) for H ∥ c*, while the g values are almost constant over the temperature range.
elements.clean_text:
The resistivity measurement was performed on single crystals with carbon paint as four-probe contacts. The measurement at room temperature shows that [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] is an insulator. 

To estimate the oxidation state of Cu, the electron spin resonance (ESR) measurement was carried out from 290 to 4 K with a Bruker EMS 9.3-GHz X-band ESR spectrometer equipped with an Oxford ITC305 cryostat. Figure  shows the angular dependences of the g value and the line width for one Lorentzian signal of the single crystal, [CuCl2(BP-TTF)2], with the crystal orientation in Figure . The g value varies from 2.05 to 2.27 when the crystal is rotated about the pseudo-4-fold axis of CuIICl2N2 coordination in 1 with the static field perpendicular to this axis (θ rotation), while the g value in the ω rotation is much smaller and the line width is nearly 4-fold rotation. This result is similar to that  of (BEDT-TTF)3CuIICl4⋅H2O, within the range for Jahn-Teller distorted CuIIX4 ions. Therefore, the Cu complex is expected to be [CuIICl2(BP-TTF)0] in correspondence with the insulating behavior without carriers. The temperature dependence of ESR measurements was carried out from 290 to 4 K in the magnetic field parallel and perpendicular to the c* axis. With lowering temperatures, the line widths decrease from 29 G (290 K) to 16 G (4 K) for H ⊥ c* and from 23 G (290 K) to 18 G (4 K) for H ∥ c*, while the g values are almost constant over the temperature range.

elements.content: Crystal orientation of [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] in the ESR rotation experiment.
elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal orientation of [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] in the ESR rotation experiment.

elements.content: Angular dependence of (a) theg value and (b) the line width for [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] at 290 K (open circle, ω rotation; filled triangle, θ rotation).
elements.clean_text: 4  Angular dependence of (a) theg value and (b) the line width for [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] at 290 K (open circle, ω rotation; filled triangle, θ rotation).

elements.content: Temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility for [CuCl2(BP-TTF)]. The solid line denotes the theoretical fitting for the 1-D Bonner−Fisher model (H = − 2J∑S i S i+1 )21 in the temperature range 2−300 K, where CuII S = 1/2 and the antiferromagnetic interaction J = −3.5 K are estimated.
elements.clean_text: 5  Temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility for [CuCl2(BP-TTF)]. The solid line denotes the theoretical fitting for the 1-D Bonner-Fisher model (H =  - 2J∑S  i  S  i+1 )21 in the temperature range 2-300 K, where CuII S = 1/2 and the antiferromagnetic interaction J = -3.5 K are estimated.

elements.content: The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility after subtraction of the Pascal diamagnetic contribution for [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] was investigated by a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer under 10 000 Oe, as shown in Figure . The magnetic susceptibility χ at 300 K is 1.334 × 10-3 emu mol-1 and fits to a Bonner−Fisher model from 2 to 300 K with S = 1/2 and J = −3.5 K. The preliminary torque measurements indicate that 1 has no long-range magnetic order down to 1.7 K. Above the hump at 4.4−300 K, χ also follows the Curie−Weiss law, χ = C/(T − θ), with θ = −7.4 K and C = 0.4076 emu mol-1 K-1. Utilizing the g value 2.12 observed from ESR measurements, the spin density is estimated at N ∼ 1 spin (S = 1/2)/formula unit. These results reveal that the oxidation states are CuII and BP-TTF0, which are in agreement with the crystal structure and transport and ESR measurements. Moreover, it should be kept in mind that CuII−CuII and CuIICl···CuII distances are at least 3.87 and 5.56 Å, respectively, so the direct and superexchange interaction between the CuII ions through Cl- can be ruled out. Therefore, it is concluded that the antiferromagnetic interaction between CuII S = 1/2 spins appears through coordinated BP-TTF donors as ligands, namely, the d−π interaction.
elements.clean_text: The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility after subtraction of the Pascal diamagnetic contribution for [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] was investigated by a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer under 10000 Oe, as shown in Figure . The magnetic susceptibility χ at 300 K is 1.334 × 10-3 emu mol-1 and fits to a Bonner-Fisher model from 2 to 300 K with S = 1/2 and J = -3.5 K. The preliminary torque measurements indicate that 1 has no long-range magnetic order down to 1.7 K. Above the hump at 4.4-300 K, χ also follows the Curie-Weiss law, χ = C/(T - θ), with θ = -7.4 K and C = 0.4076 emu mol-1 K-1. Utilizing the g value 2.12 observed from ESR measurements, the spin density is estimated at N ~ 1 spin (S = 1/2)/formula unit. These results reveal that the oxidation states are CuII and BP-TTF0, which are in agreement with the crystal structure and transport and ESR measurements. Moreover, it should be kept in mind that CuII-CuII and CuIICl⋅⋅⋅CuII distances are at least 3.87 and 5.56 Å, respectively, so the direct and superexchange interaction between the CuII ions through Cl- can be ruled out. Therefore, it is concluded that the antiferromagnetic interaction between CuII S = 1/2 spins appears through coordinated BP-TTF donors as ligands, namely, the d-π interaction.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have synthesized the CuII complex with pyrazino-fused TTF as the ligand, [CuCl2(BP-TTF)]. The crystal structure reveals the 3-D supramolecular framework, where the 1-D zigzag chain [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] n extends along the b axis, the BP-TTF donors stack to form columns along the c axis, and the donor side-by-side interactions appear in the a axis. Owing to this supramolecular structure, the magnetic susceptibility measurement demonstrates the antiferromagnetic interactions between CuII S = 1/2 spins mediated by BP-TTF donors, namely, d−π interactions. A further study aimed at the synergetic action of magnetism and conductivity in the novel CuII complex with other pyrazino-fused donors is promising to open to the novel d−π system.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we have synthesized the CuII complex with pyrazino-fused TTF as the ligand, [CuCl2(BP-TTF)]. The crystal structure reveals the 3-D supramolecular framework, where the 1-D zigzag chain [CuCl2(BP-TTF)] n  extends along the b axis, the BP-TTF donors stack to form columns along the c axis, and the donor side-by-side interactions appear in the a axis. Owing to this supramolecular structure, the magnetic susceptibility measurement demonstrates the antiferromagnetic interactions between CuII S = 1/2 spins mediated by BP-TTF donors, namely, d-π interactions. A further study aimed at the synergetic action of magnetism and conductivity in the novel CuII complex with other pyrazino-fused donors is promising to open to the novel d-π system.

metadata.title:
Antiferromagnetic Interaction Achieved by a 3-D Supramolecular CuII
Complex with Pyrazino-Fused TTF as the Ligand, [CuCl2(BP-TTF)]
